author: Gustavo Gamarra
title: XPG LANCER RGB DDR5: Rompen el récord mundial de OC con 12762 MT/s
text:
XPG bate el récord mundial de velocidad de memoria con sus LANCER RGB DDR5 . La velocidad de reloj con overclocking alcanzó unos 12.762 MT/s .
XPG LANCER RGB DDR5: Rompen el récord con 12762 MT/s
XPG quiere demostrar que sus memorias LANCER RGB DDR5 son las de mayor rendimiento en el mundo, batiendo un nuevo récord mundial de OC, que fue llevado a cabo por el conocido overclocker HiCookie de Gigabyte.
HiCookie utilizo unas memorias RAM LANCER RGB DDR5 de 8000 MT/s junto a una placa base Z890 AORUS TACHYON ICE de Gigabyte y el uso de nitrógeno líquido (LN2) para la refrigeración. El procesador seleccionado fue el Intel Core Ultra 9 285K .
Te recomendamos nuestra guía sobre las mejores memorias RAM del mercado
La placa base Z890 AORUS TACHYON ICE cuenta con una serie de funciones centradas en el overclocking, donde se incluye un botón de overclocking y una opción precisamente diseñada para un modo con nitrógeno líquido LN2. Es decir, la placa base ya está preparada para este tipo de overclocking extremo.
Con esta configuración y las manos del overclocker Hicookie, se logró unas velocidades de 12762 MT/s , alcanzando un récord de OC con una memoria DDR5. Este logro fue certificado en HWBOT.
Gigabyte ha comentado que se implementó la tecnología de aprendizaje automático e inteligencia artificial en sus placas base para determinar de forma precisa las configuraciones optimizadas para lograr la estabilidad y la eficiencia en el overclocking.
Por su parte, las memorias XPG LANCER RGB DDR5 vienen con dos chips incorporados, PMIC (Power Management Integrated Circuit) de alta calidad y tecnología ECC (Error Correction Code). Estas memorias vienen en capacidades de 16 GB, 32 GB y hasta 48 GB con velocidades que varían entre los 6000 MT/s y 8000 MT/s . Por supuesto, son totalmente compatibles con los perfiles Intel XMP 3.0 y AMD EXPO, por lo que funcionan muy bien en las plataformas de Intel o de AMD. Pueden ver más información en el siguiente enlace .

author: Елена Шмакова
title: Смертельная опасность: планирующих отдых в Турции граждан России предупредили о риске заражения ящуром
text:
Смертельная опасность: планирующих отдых в Турции граждан России предупредили о риске заражения ящуром
Эксперты предупредили туристов из России об увеличении числа заражений ящуром в Турции. Острое вирусное заболевание смертельно опасно.
Турецкие власти приняли решение о приостановке деятельности всех животноводческих рынков в стране после участившихся случаев ящура, которые всё больше отмечались в стане после праздников Курбан-байрама. Острое вирусное заболевание передаётся человеку от больных животных. Чаще всего ящуром заражаются свиньи и крупный рогатый скот. Источником инфекции служат больные животные, в том числе находящиеся в инкубационном периоде болезни. Вирус может выделяться вместе со слюной, мочой, навозом, молоком.
Ящур, по словам экспертов, может передаваться через прямой контакт с заражённым животным, термически необработанными мясными изделиями или молочными продуктами. Вирус также устойчив низким температурам и может сохраняться в обычном молоке. Однако ящур погибнет под воздействием высокой температуры всего за 5 минут. Заразиться человеку вероятность небольшая, но симптомы болезни могут быть тяжёлыми, например, высыпания на коже и повышенная температура тела, сообщает RG.RU.
Уважаемые читатели "Царьграда"!
Присоединяйтесь к нам в соцсетях "ВКонтакте" и "Одноклассники".

author: Lucretia Munro
title: Iconic Carry On star revealed as World War Two hero who helped plan Great Escape - Mirror Online
text:
Carry On legendary actor Peter Butterworth has been revealed as a World War Two hero who helped plan the Great Escape from Stalag Luft camp in Poland.
According to the National Archives, Peter, who was best known for his cheeky one-liners, was a POW [a prisoner of war] who helped 76 airmen flee Poland on March 24 1944, one year before the war ended. The actor, who was then known as Lt Butterworth realised he could pass coded messages to the British Intelligence, as the prisoners were allowed to write letters home to their loved ones.
More than four decades on from his death in 1979, Dr Will Butler, of the National Archives, said: "He was a talented artist and is noted in the camp records as a highly skilled forger of documents." The Great Escape was turned into a hit movie starring screen icon Steve McQueen in 1963.
Peter was an airman with the Fleet Air Arm but was targeted and shot down at the beginning of the second World War and spent the remainder of his time as a prisoner of war. Peter staged an escape through tunnels and managed to release himself from prison for six weeks but was unfortunately caught by a member of the Hitler Youth.
He tragically passed away while performing a pantomime playing Widow Twankey in Aladdin at the Coventry Theatre. He was found dead in his hotel room from a suspected heart attack. For more than 60 years, Carry On films brought light humour and escapism to the home of many households across the nation and made stars out of actors including Kenneth Williams , Barbara Windsor and Sid James. But it seems life wasn't one big ball of fun for Peter.
The docu-series Carry On - Secrets and Scandals revealed the darker side to acting in the legendary films. The documentary showed an unseen interview with Barbara Windsor where she exposed the fact the cast did not get paid for any repeats of the films. Peter Rogers produced the hit films and was reportedly known for being tight-fisted and not paying his cast.
At the time, the Mirror reported that at a 40th anniversary dinner, Peter joked: "Most important of all, of course, are the artists. I love them very much and would do anything for them except pay them more money." Three years ago it was revealed that Peter was turned down for a role playing himself in a film based on a prisoner of war escape plot, because he was "too fat."
Peter Butterworth auditioned for the part in the 1950 film The Wooden Horse, which was centered on how a group of PoWs dug a tunnel out of the Stalag Luft III camp. However, the casting director reportedly said he was not "convincingly heroic or athletic enough" for the role. And when Peter asked him to elaborate, he was told: "You're too fat."
As a prisoner of war, Peter was taken under armed guard to his first prison camp near Frankfurt. While there Peter, along with a few others, used soup spoons to dig an escape tunnel from under a bed, which took them six months. At that time 17 men escaped. But Peter was found in woods six weeks later by Hitler Youth, and ended up in Stalag Luft III, near Sagan in Nazi-occupied Poland.
